citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
A female alpaca, approximately 13 years old, named Wilma was identified during the inspection to have overgrown
toenails on all 4 feet. The nails were beginning to curl and Wilma walked with an altered gait when encouraged to move.
According to the facility representatives, Wilma had had her toenails trimmed in June when she was sheared but they
were unaware that they needed to be trimmed again. Not maintaining properly trimmed toenails may result in pain and
discomfort to the animal. Each exhibitor shall establish and maintain programs of veterinary care that include the use of
appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose, and treat diseases and injuries. Correct by obtaining adequate and
appropriate footcare for Wilma.
***Correct by 12/27/24.

citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
A neutered, adult, male sugar glider named Gomez was found on Thursday, May 23, 2024 to be stuck inside its fabric
hammock pouch with a string wrapped around a rear foot. Gomez was freed from the pouch and the string was removed
from the foot. On Saturday, May 25th, 2024, zookeepers contacted the attending veterinarian (AV) with concerns about
Gomez, but the attending veterinarian was not in over the weekend. According to facility records, on 5/28/24, Gomez was
brought to the AV for an exam and an amputation was performed on the leg. Upon inquiring with the attending
veterinarian, the AV conveyed to USDA that had Gomez received care sooner, Gomez’s medical needs would not have
been as severe as they were. However, Gomez did recover after medical care.
Each exhibitor shall ensure that daily observations are performed on all animals to assess their health and well-being.
Frequent communications with the attending veterinarian are required to allow for the veterinarian to advise licensees on
needed treatments for health concerns, which helps to mitigate the effects of adverse health conditions. Correct by
ensuring that thorough daily observations are made to promptly identify health concerns, and that frequent
communications with the AV address the concerns with proper veterinary care.
***Correct on 12/6/24 going forward.

The front of the large outdoor enclosure housing one adult female camel has a service door with a large open area above
it, as well as fencing with spaces large enough to allow the general public to interact directly with the camel. There is also
a gap approximately 5 inches wide between a fence pole and the shelter building.
During public exhibition, any animal must be handled so that there is minimal risk of harm to the animals and to the public,
with sufficient distance and/or barriers between the animal and the general viewing public so as to assure the safety of
animals and the public. Allowing people to touch and interact directly with the camel without the supervision of a
responsible attendant does not ensure the safety of the animal or the general public. Correct by ensuring that there is
sufficient distance and/or barriers between the camel and public during exhibition to protect both the animals and the
public.
***Correct by 12/20/24.

The wooden shelter building for two adult alpacas was found to have gaps between all of the boards on one side of the
building. Gaps do not prevent wind and precipitation from entering the shelter and do not provide the animals adequate
protection against the elements in the case of severe weather. Natural or artificial shelters appropriate to the local climatic
conditions for the species concerned shall be provided for all animals kept outdoors to afford them protection and to
prevent discomfort to such animals. Correct by ensuring that the alpaca shelter is appropriate to protect the animals from
harsh elements.
***Correct by 12/27/24.

The keeper access door for the aviary area housing 2 macaws and 2 parrots is in disrepair with multiple areas of the
wooden frame and metal mesh affected. There are small holes in the door as well as wire points protruding from the door
into the primary enclosure which could potentially contact the animals. Primary enclosures must be constructed and
maintained in good repair to protect the birds from injury, contain the birds securely, and restrict other animals from
entering the enclosure. Correct by maintaining the door and entire primary enclosure in good repair.
***Correct by 12/20/24.
This is a continuation of the report for the routine inspection conducted on 12/5/24 and 12/6/24 with the facility
representatives. This report contains the remaining non-compliances found during the inspection. The exit briefing for the
items included on this report was conducted on 12/6/24 with the facility representatives.
n

narrative:
2.40(b)(2) 
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
A female alpaca, approximately 13 years old, named Wilma was identified during the inspection to have overgrown 
toenails on all 4 feet. The nails were beginning to curl and Wilma walked with an altered gait when encouraged to move. 
According to the facility representatives, Wilma had had her toenails trimmed in June when she was sheared but they 
were unaware that they needed to be trimmed again. Not maintaining properly trimmed toenails may result in pain and 
discomfort to the animal. Each exhibitor shall establish and maintain programs of veterinary care that include the use of 
appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose, and treat diseases and injuries. Correct by obtaining adequate and 
appropriate footcare for Wilma. 
 
***Correct by 12/27/24. 
2.40(b)(3)  Critical
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
A neutered, adult, male sugar glider named Gomez was found on Thursday, May 23, 2024 to be stuck inside its fabric 
hammock pouch with a string wrapped around a rear foot. Gomez was freed from the pouch and the string was removed 
from the foot. On Saturday, May 25th, 2024, zookeepers contacted the attending veterinarian (AV) with concerns about 
Gomez, but the attending veterinarian was not in over the weekend. According to facility records, on 5/28/24, Gomez was 
brought to the AV for an exam and an amputation was performed on the leg. Upon inquiring with the attending 
veterinarian, the AV conveyed to USDA that had Gomez received care sooner, Gomez’s medical needs would not have 
been as severe as they were. However, Gomez did recover after medical care.  
 
Each exhibitor shall ensure that daily observations are performed on all animals to assess their health and well-being. 
Frequent communications with the attending veterinarian are required to allow for the veterinarian to advise licensees on 
needed treatments for health concerns, which helps to mitigate the effects of adverse health conditions. Correct by 
ensuring that thorough daily observations are made to promptly identify health concerns, and that frequent 
communications with the AV address the concerns with proper veterinary care.  
 
***Correct on 12/6/24 going forward.

2.131(c)(1) 
   
Handling of animals. 
The front of the large outdoor enclosure housing one adult female camel has a service door with a large open area above 
it, as well as fencing with spaces large enough to allow the general public to interact directly with the camel. There is also 
a gap approximately 5 inches wide between a fence pole and the shelter building.  
 
During public exhibition, any animal must be handled so that there is minimal risk of harm to the animals and to the public, 
with sufficient distance and/or barriers between the animal and the general viewing public so as to assure the safety of 
animals and the public. Allowing people to touch and interact directly with the camel without the supervision of a 
responsible attendant does not ensure the safety of the animal or the general public. Correct by ensuring that there is 
sufficient distance and/or barriers between the camel and public during exhibition to protect both the animals and the 
public.  
 
***Correct by 12/20/24. 
3.127(b) 
   
Facilities, outdoor. 
The wooden shelter building for two adult alpacas was found to have gaps between all of the boards on one side of the 
building. Gaps do not prevent wind and precipitation from entering the shelter and do not provide the animals adequate 
protection against the elements in the case of severe weather. Natural or artificial shelters appropriate to the local climatic 
conditions for the species concerned shall be provided for all animals kept outdoors to afford them protection and to 
prevent discomfort to such animals. Correct by ensuring that the alpaca shelter is appropriate to protect the animals from 
harsh elements.  
 
***Correct by 12/27/24. 
3.153(a)(1) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
The keeper access door for the aviary area housing 2 macaws and 2 parrots is in disrepair with multiple areas of the 
wooden frame and metal mesh affected. There are small holes in the door as well as wire points protruding from the door 
into the primary enclosure which could potentially contact the animals. Primary enclosures must be constructed and 
maintained in good repair to protect the birds from injury, contain the birds securely, and restrict other animals from 
entering the enclosure. Correct by maintaining the door and entire primary enclosure in good repair.  
 
***Correct by 12/20/24. 
 
This is a continuation of the report for the routine inspection conducted on 12/5/24 and 12/6/24 with the facility 
representatives. This report contains the remaining non-compliances found during the inspection. The exit briefing for the 
items included on this report was conducted on 12/6/24 with the facility representatives.
